content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player who is comfortable with taking risks, I would choose to play this game strategically by not assuming my anonymous opponent's actions. Given that there are 75 rounds, it's important to consider the long-term payoff rather than focusing on individual rounds.

If I consistently choose R, and my opponent chooses B every time, I will end up with 0$ for each of the 75 rounds, receiving no payoff at all. On the other hand, if I consistently choose B while my opponent chooses R, I would get 42$ in each round, totaling 3180$.

However, if I mix up my choices between R and B, there's a chance that I could get the maximum payoff of 45$ per round when both of us choose R. In order to maximize this potential outcome, I should aim for a near-even distribution between choosing R and choosing B over the course of the 75 rounds.

While my opponent might try to exploit my strategy by choosing R whenever I play B and choosing B whenever I play R, I can minimize their ability to do so by varying my choices unpredictably. This approach allows me to maximize my potential payoff in a way that doesn't depend on the actions of my anonymous opponent.

Choosing R as a human player: {R}
